content.text: How long did it take for the vehicle to travel from Y to X?
Calculate the average speed of the vehicle as it travels from Y to X
average speed = .........
How does its speed at X compare with that at Y?
Tick one box
greater than at Y
same as that at Y
less than that at Y
How does its speed at X compare with the average speed calculated in **(b)**?
Tick one box
[Total: 7]
The vehicle in **(a)** and **(b)** is accelerating as it travels from Y to X
Two boys, X and Y, decide to measure the speed of some of the vehicles travelling road. The two boys stand \(405 \text{m}\) apart beside the road, as shown in Fig. 1.1
Boy X has a stopwatch which he sets to zero. As a vehicle passes boy Y, boy Y drops his hand as a signal to boy X to start his stopwatch. Boy X then stops the stopwatch as the vehicle goes past him
The appearance of the stopwatch is then as shown in Fig. 1.2
Solids, liquids and gases have different properties. The list below gives some of them
Use descriptions from the list to complete the table. Any description may be used more than once if appropriate. Two spaces have been filled in to help you

table.html:
shapemolecules
(a) solid
(b) liquidmove around, close together
(c) gascompletely fills the container

content.text: Here is a list of energy resources available to the world. Some of these are renewable some are non-renewable

In the second blank column, put a tick by any **two** resources that are non-renewable

Name the process by which thermal energy is transferred
As thermal energy is supplied, the temperature of the water begins to rise. Although the supply of energy remains constant, eventually the temperature becomes steady at about \(80^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\)
Suggest why this happens
State what is now happening to the water
What gas do the bubbles contain? Tick one box
[Total: 5]
The rate of energy supply is increased. The temperature of the water begins to rise again, but eventually becomes steady at a higher temperature. This time many bubbles are seen throughout the water
